Award.AwardTitle: I-6 Challenge: CLEAR-View: A cost effective thermal sensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
K&A Wireless has requested support for a one year membership to the New Mexico Technology Ventures Corporation that was recently selected as the recipient of the Economic Development Administrations Region 5 i6 award. The focus of the I-6 effort will be on developing a short range wireless video system that is capable of distributing the power requirements of the CLIR-View algorithm to market segments where handheld thermal imaging devices are required, like firefighting and military.

This development and commercialization will utilize interns from the University of New Mexico and New Mexico State to provide real world experience to these undergraduate students. In addition, the intent is to create a position for one of the students on a full time basis after graduation at the end of the program. In addition, the focus is to bring a new hardware product to market which will help in the economic development of the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the I-6 for K&A was to commercialze a short-range wireless video technology capable of distributing the processing power (i.e. power consumption, batteries, etc.) due to image processing on an individual that carries a multitude of equipment, such as first responders or military personnel.

The most important finding in the I-6 is the implementation of Lean Launchpad developed and taught by Prof. Steve Blank at University of California, Berkeley – Hass School of Business and at Stanford University[1]. Using this approach, the vision for the commercialization of the technology became crystal clear. In addition, working closely with Technology Ventures Corporation (I-6 winner in the Austin region) who provided seminars on different aspects of the business process (from developing marketing plans to the patent writing workshop, and everything else in between). The team at K&A attended numerous seminars and have been implementing and executing on what we have learned from these seminars and incorporating them into the business model canvas. In addition, we are working closely with our portfolio manager to refine our business plans and to prepare the business for external investment. We are currently in the process of exchanging what we've learned with Lean Launchpad with TVC to further help refine their services as well.

The concept of Lean Launchpad is the ability to look at generating a viable, scalable business model as the focus of a startup and not just a product, or the features of a product, being developed or commercialized. By choosing to bring a minimum viable product to customers and letting the customers finish the development for you, the company must refine any, and all, aspects of the business model to ensure success. Business schools and consultants historically work around, and with, the execution of known business models, (accounting, organizational behavior, managerial skills, marketing, operations, etc.).

When commercializing a technology, we have to assume the business model is not known, even though the product or service may be viable. Success (i.e. a scalable business) comes from where the product viability and the business model viability intersect – both are critical.We started by mapping our assumptions (our business model) and then we tested these hypotheses with customers and partners outside in the field (customer development) and used an iterative and incremental development methodology (agile development) to build the product.

The goal was to get out of the building to test each of the 9 parts of our business model, understand which of these assumptions were wrong, and figure out what we needed to do to fix it. Our objective was to get users, orders, customers, etc. all delivered fast.  The key was to test our hypotheses and make adjustments when we learned that our original assumptions about the business are wrong. We wanted to experience faulty assumptions not as a crisis, but as a learning experience called a pivot —an opportunity to change the business model.


[1] http://steveblank.com/category/lean-launchpad/
